Posts.Content: May 14, 2007 05:14PM stronglady wrote: For what it's worth: my LE therapists suggests not getting the bracelet, because in a crisis, medical personnel might not realize it has medical information on it
Posts.Title: Medical Alert Bracelets yankeedownsouth PixieDust

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2007 02:57AM stronglady wrote: Sorry I didn't respond to people's questions back in May. My LE therapist's objections to bracelets are twofold: 1) she's not convinced that emergency personnel actually look at them, 2) she thinks the ones that look like jewelry are particularly likely to be overlooked. So she says that if you're going to wear one, make sure it's the ugly, traditional medic alert style. (Personally, I found one that's sort of in-between: it has a jewelry-like bracelet with a big ugly medic alert-type tag. So, as Rose suggests, I can turn it over to look like a bracelet in meetings, etc.)
Posts.Title: Medical Alert Bracelets yankeedownsouth PixieDust

Posts.Content: Dec 25, 2006 06:47AM stronglady wrote: I'm not sure about the moving around part, but my lymphedema specialist informs me that after radiation, you can get scar tissue around your ribs - scar tissue can continue to build for 1 1/2 years after treatment, especially near the upper ribs, which got radiated. She advocates massaging the area (circular motion with fingers) to break up the scar tissue. Although it hurts to do, it helps in the long run. Hope this helps.

Posts.Content: stronglady wrote: Hi, folks. This is partly a rant and partly a question. My LE had been doing really well lately: the arm measurements were in the normal range, I was wrapping at night and wearing a sleeve & gauntlet during the day. Also wrapping to exercise. I'd never had any hand swelling except in the early days, when we were adjusting the bandaging. Then, a couple of weeks ago, my knuckles started to swell. I assumed it was because the gauntlet had started to stretch out. Fortunately, another gauntlet had been ordered to replace a defective one (what did I used to do with my time?). So since Thursday, I've been wearing the new gauntlet. Yesterday, my fingers swelled up for the first time in a gauntlet. So now I can't figure out whether: a) the original knuckle-swelling really meant that a gauntlet is no longer adequate and I now need a glove (DARN!) or b) the new gauntlet is a problem. I'll call me LE therapist and the gauntlet provider tomorrow, and I'm bandaged up for now. So the question part: has anyone else had their lymphedema show up in new places after months (in my case, around 8 months) of treatment? Or longer? And the rant part: I just needed to have people who would understand it when I say that THIS STINKS!!!!!!!!!! -Leslie Stay strong! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: apparent setback stronglady neat

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2007 11:48PM stronglady wrote: That's interesting..when I was treated for tennis elbow, I had a PT w/ LE therapy experience (in addition to my LE therapist). They thought there was a cycle going: the fluid from the LE pressed on the tendons, and the inflammation of the tendons increased the swelling. So the therapy kind of attacked on all fronts, trying to reduce both the inflammation and the swelling. For example, after a round of 'regular' tennis elbow PT, I got the arm massaged, with emphasis on the elbow, to move the fluid out.
Posts.Title: Aching elbow juliehere BMD

Posts.Content: stronglady wrote: Hi, folks. I was fitted with a new sleeve last week (after another intensive round of bandaging, 24/7). It's working better than my old one, but I've got a rash on the point of my elbow. I'm using extra moisturizer & keri oil after my shower, and am applying steroid cream. I hope it will clear up w/ the cream, and the extra moisturizer will keep it from recurring. Any other ideas? BTW: I suppose it's possibly from all the bandaging, and I just didnt' notice it - if so, I've had it before, and this approach worked before. But I think it's unlikely I failed to notice. Thanks!
